[[Image:Microsoft Office Word 2003 on ubuntu.png|thumb|300px|A screenshot of [[Microsoft Word]] 2003 running under Wine]]
'''Wine''' is a [[software application]] which aims to allow [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s on the [[x86 architecture]] to execute programs written for [[Microsoft Windows]]. Wine also provides a [[software library]] known as ''Winelib'' against which developers can [[compiler|compile]] Windows applications to help [[porting|port]] them to Unix-like systems.<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.winehq.org/site/winelib | publisher = Wine HQ | title = Winelib | accessdate = 2008-06-29 }}</ref>
'''Wine''' is a [[software application]] which aims to allow [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s on the [[x86 architecture]] to execute programs written for [[Microsoft Windows]]. Wine also provides a [[software library]] known as ''Winelib'' against which developers can [[compiler|compile]] Windows applications to help [[porting|port]] them to Unix-like systems.<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.winehq.org/site/winelib | publisher = Wine HQ | title = Winelib | accessdate = 2008-06-29 }}</ref>
Line 54: Line 54:
== Functionality ==
== Functionality ==
â
[[Image:Wine configuration screenshot.png|right|220px|thumb|Screenshot of winecfg.]]
 
As of mid-[[As of 2007|2007]], Wine runs some software with good stability and most software with minor issues.<ref>[http://appdb.winehq.org/ Wine AppDB - Wine Application Database<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Most native Microsoft Windows DLLs necessary for the execution of 32-bit Windows binaries have compatible Wine counterparts. The developers of the [[Direct3D]] portions of Wine have continued to implement new features such as [[pixel shaders]] to increase game support.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.winehq.org/DirectX-Shaders | title = DirectX-Shaders-The Official Wine Wiki }}</ref> Wine can also use native DLLs directly, thus increasing functionality, but then a license for Windows is needed unless the DLLs were distributed with the application itself.
As of mid-[[As of 2007|2007]], Wine runs some software with good stability and most software with minor issues.<ref>[http://appdb.winehq.org/ Wine AppDB - Wine Application Database<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Most native Microsoft Windows DLLs necessary for the execution of 32-bit Windows binaries have compatible Wine counterparts. The developers of the [[Direct3D]] portions of Wine have continued to implement new features such as [[pixel shaders]] to increase game support.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.winehq.org/DirectX-Shaders | title = DirectX-Shaders-The Official Wine Wiki }}</ref> Wine can also use native DLLs directly, thus increasing functionality, but then a license for Windows is needed unless the DLLs were distributed with the application itself.
